Description: Egyptian terracotta figure of horses' head. Head only with rider missing, apart from hands. Hand-made and solid. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with black core. Abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Crude hand-made horses and cavalry figures are commonly found in the Delta in end of the Late Period or early Ptolemaic contexts and generally dated to the 4th and sometimes as late as the 3rd century BC. Horses' heads (for either simple hand-made riders or Persian rider types) were found at Deir el-Bahari and dated to the Ptolemaic period (Cairo Museum nos JE58768-74=SR5/559-65). They vary greatly from small crude figures (British Museum EA 1886,0802.63), such as those from Naukratis (British Museum Higgins 1954, 407, GR 1886,0401.1468), to more complicated examples with a mould made Persian style rider. This is probably of the latter type. Many parallels found at Naukratis (British Museum GR 1888,0601.90, Cairo SR5/966, CG 32804, Cambridge MCA NA602, NA603, NA604), Tanis (Dunand 1990: 215-6, Cat. 583-592 and 594-595, particularly 585), Memphis (Cairo SR5/6260; Petrie 1909a, pl.40. nos 42 , 45, 46; Petrie 1909b, pl.29), Tell Basta (Cairo National Museum CG32810 SR5/967), Tukh el-Karamus (CG32806 JE35660 SR5/895), Deir el Bakari (CG32807 JE36203 SR5/896, CG32808 JE36203 SR5/897), Alexandria (Fischer 1994, nos 20-21) and without provenance (Cairo National Museum SR5/970 CG32907, ST5/969 CG32904, TR22/11/22/1 SR5/906, TR22/11/22/2 SR5/907, TR22/11/22/3 SR5/908, C32902 SR5/898). Being handmade, each horse is slightly different in each case. Figurines of this type are often called ‘Persian riders’ because the rider has sharp-crested headgear and ‘Asiatic’ beards. They are dated by various scholars to between the 7th or 6th century BC (Edgar in Hogarth et. al. 1905, 129; Petrie 1909a, pl. 40), the mid 4th (Higgins 1954, 407, no. 1549) and the 4th to 3rd century BC (Dunand 1990, 215-6, nos 583-589, 591, particularly 591 and 585). Achaemenid terracotta ‘Persian riders’ found at Dura Europos are similar in style and were made using the same technique (Downey 2003, 142-53, no.91). Parallels from Uruk are dated 999BC-500BC (Ziegler 1963, pl.39, nos 484-9, see also horses and riders pls 40-42, nos 482-536) and Nippur dated broadly 600BC-300BC, but specifically Persian, c.500BC and a date before 450BC (McCown 1967, pls 47-49, nos 245-262 especially pl. 47, no.245). This suggests one should associate these with the Achaemenid rule of Egypt between 525BC and 332BC. Hogarth cites Cypriot and Phoenician parallels for the ‘Persian rider’ type and other crude limestone and terracotta horsemen found at Naukratis (Edgar in Hogarth et al. 1905, 129). One example from Naukratis (Cambridge, MCA NA603) appears to be from the same mould as another example found at Memphis (Petrie 1909, pl.40, no. 46), suggesting that these were transported up and down the Nile branches.
